Usage

Source: vignettes/usage.Rmd
usage.Rmd

Local task queues

crew’s multi-session task queue is much like https://www.tidyverse.org/blog/2019/09/callr-task-q/. To start a queue, call crew_queue_session$new() and supply the number of workers, or background processes, that are capable of accepting tasks.

queue <- crew_queue_session$new(workers = 2)

Immediately, two background processes start. We can inspect them with the get_workers() method. The handle column is a list column with callr::r_session handles.

queue$get_workers()
#> # A tibble: 2 × 8
#>   worker                         handle     free  sent  up    done  task  input 
#>   <chr>                          <list>     <lgl> <lgl> <lgl> <lgl> <chr> <list>
#> 1 xb9e0b01b_9643_4fb0_947e_6a7b… <r_sessin> TRUE  FALSE FALSE FALSE NA    <list>
#> 2 xa52a8285_1fed_44d4_b468_b22f… <r_sessin> TRUE  FALSE FALSE FALSE NA    <list>

No tasks are waiting to be assigned to workers,

queue$get_tasks()
#> # A tibble: 0 × 2
#> # … with 2 variables: task <chr>, input <list>

and no results are available from completed tasks.

queue$get_results()
#> # A tibble: 0 × 2
#> # … with 2 variables: task <chr>, result <list>

To assign a task, we create a function in R and a named list of arguments. We supply that information to the push() method of the queue.

fun <- function(seconds) {
  Sys.sleep(seconds)
  return(paste("ran for", seconds, "seconds and completed successfully"))
}
  
queue$push(fun = fun, args = list(seconds = 1))

Control returns to the main R session immediately, and the the task runs in the background. Call pop() to check on the results and return the latest one if available.

while (is.null(result <- queue$pop())) {
  Sys.sleep(0.25)
  message("still waiting")
}
#> still waiting
#> still waiting
#> still waiting
#> still waiting

str(result)
#> List of 2
#>  $ task  : chr "x18a7ff1c_efcb_4abb_8c4e_cd436dd7cf0c"
#>  $ result:List of 6
#>   ..$ code   : int 200
#>   ..$ message: chr "done callr-rs-result-36c72eb7d4b2"
#>   ..$ result : chr "ran for 1 seconds and completed successfully"
#>   ..$ stdout : chr ""
#>   ..$ stderr : chr ""
#>   ..$ error  : NULL
#>   ..- attr(*, "class")= chr "callr_session_result"
result$result$result
#> [1] "ran for 1 seconds and completed successfully"

Internally, push() and pop() call the update() method,1 which is like the schedule() method in the 100-line task queue. update() shuffles waiting tasks to available works, checks if workers are done (or crashed), and collects output so it is available for get_results() or pop(). It is recommended to invoke the task queue at regular intervals to assign new tasks and collect results. Here is a sketch of such an event loop. The targets package and heavy-duty Shiny apps have event loops like this one.

fun <- function(seconds) {
  Sys.sleep(seconds)
  seconds
}

tasks <- runif(n = 25, min = 0.1, max = 1)
results <- numeric(0)

for (task in tasks) {
  queue$push(fun = fun, args = list(seconds = task))
  result <- queue$pop()
  if (!is.null(result)) {
    results <- c(results, result$result$result)
  }
}

while (length(results) < length(tasks)) {
  result <- queue$pop()
  if (!is.null(result)) {
    results <- c(results, result$result$result)
  }
}

Because the tasks run asynchronously, they may finish in a different order than you submitted them.

round(tasks, 3)
#>  [1] 0.190 0.385 0.567 0.696 0.466 0.922 0.364 0.513 0.399 0.686 0.332 0.531
#> [13] 0.790 0.176 0.888 0.405 0.855 0.412 0.400 0.529 0.903 0.878 0.451 0.800
#> [25] 0.965
round(results, 3)
#>  [1] 0.190 0.385 0.567 0.696 0.466 0.364 0.922 0.513 0.399 0.332 0.686 0.531
#> [13] 0.176 0.790 0.405 0.888 0.412 0.855 0.400 0.529 0.903 0.878 0.451 0.800
#> [25] 0.965

When you are done with the queue, call the shutdown() method to terminate the workers.

queue$shutdown()

Other task queues

The crew_queue_future task queue uses transient future’s as workers. The queue has a default future::plan(), and you can set an individual plan for each task you push. The plan can either be the sequential plan or a plan from future.batchtools^[other plans are not supported because they cannot be sent to the callr::r_session workers in the subqueue). future.batchtools workers have high overhead for submitting, polling, and collecting tasks, so crew_queue_future supports a subqueue, a local multi-process queue inside the larger queue to asynchronously manage the future’s internally.

A crew_queue_future queue is created just like a crew_queue_session queue, except there are a couple more arguments.

queue <- crew_queue_future(
  workers = 16, # Max future workers running at a time,
  store = crew_store_local$new(root = "my_store"),
  plan = future.batchtools::batchtools_slurm(template = "my_template.tmpl"),
  subqueue = crew_queue_session$new(workers = 4)
)

The meanings of most of these arguments are covered in the paragraph above. The store argument is a local data store for sending and receiving work that the future’s do. For future.batchtools futures, the root of the data store should point to a file system that all the workers can access, not just the main R process on the login node.

  1. Actually, they all call the private update_all() method, and the public update() method does nothing else.↩︎
